Louisville native Rhodes to drive for Dale Jr.

Jonathan Lintner, jlintner@courier-journal.com 11:45 a.m. EST December 5, 2014

    Ben Rhodes, pictured Aug. 1, stands on the grid during qualifying for a K&N Pro Series East event at the Iowa Speedway.(Photo: By Jonathan Moore/Getty Images)

    1 CONNECT 6 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

    Louisville native Ben Rhodes made the next step in his climb up the NASCAR ladder on Friday — and a mighty big one at that — when it was announced the Louisville native will drive 10 races next year in the XFINITY (formerly Nationwide) Series for Dale Earnhardt Jr.'s team.

    Rhodes, who will turn 18 before his first Xfinity Series start rolls around May 17 at Iowa Speedway, is set to pilot the JR Motorsports No. 88 Chevrolet shared with top-level Sprint Cup Series drivers Earnhardt Jr., Kasey Kahne and reigning champion Kevin Harvick.

    "It's all pretty surreal to me because of the people involved here," said Rhodes, a Holy Cross High School senior who also ran in four Camping World Truck Series races last season. "I've always looked up to those guys growing up. I'm excited for this wonderful opportunity I've been given, and I'm going to make the most of it."

    COURIER-JOURNAL

    Louisville driver Ben Rhodes named one of NASCAR's most-popular

    Alpha Energy Solutions, a Louisville-based company where Rhodes' father Joe serves as president, has signed on to sponsor his portion of the schedule. The mechanical service provider also backed Rhodes' 2014 championship season in the K&N Pro Series East, a regional touring circuit on which he won five races and posted 11 top-five finishes.

    Following Rhodes' May 17 XFINITY Series debut, other races on his schedule are at Chicagoland Speedway (June 20), New Hampshire Motor Speedway (July 18), a second event at Iowa (Aug. 1), Watkins Glen International (Aug. 8), Mid-Ohio Sports Car Course (Aug. 15), Road America (Aug. 29), Kentucky Speedway (Sept. 26), Dover International Speedway (Oct. 3) and the season finale at Homestead-Miami Speedway (Nov. 21).

    "Ben is one of the rising talents in NASCAR," JR Motorsports general manager Kelley Earnhardt Miller said. "As a company, JRM takes pride in cultivating young drivers, and together with Alpha Energy Solutions, we're thrilled to give Ben a platform to further develop his skills at the next level. I'm excited to see what this coming year will bring for him and the 88 team."

    COURIER-JOURNAL

    Louisville driver Ben Rhodes chasing NASCAR dreams

    While Rhodes' slate stands at 10 races now and starts after his high school graduation, he said he's open to running more, be it in the XFINITY Series or back in the K&N Pro Series East.

    JR Motorsports captured its first Nationwide Series title this year with 18-year-old Chase Elliott, who will return in the No. 9 car in 2015. Regan Smith, a former Cup Series driver, will also be back with the team's No. 7 team. The No. 88, crew chiefed by former Hendrick Motorsports engineer Dave Elenz, will compete with Rhodes and three veterans who know how to find speed in a car.

    "I plan on working in the shop every day with the team this summer," Rhodes said. "I'll be around Dale Earnhardt and Kasey Kahne and Kevin Harvick. With that, I'm going to try and use all the insight that they have."

    Earnhardt Jr., an 11-time most-popular driver, has fielded cars in NASCAR's second-tier national series since 2003, when his race team was called Chance 2 Motorsports and won a pair of titles with Martin Truex Jr. at the wheel. Since running under the JR Motorsports banner, he's facilitated the rise of current Cup Series regulars Brad Keselowski, Danica Patrick and Aric Almirola.

    COURIER-JOURNAL

    Louisville driver Ben Rhodes wins NASCAR K&N Pro Series East championship

    Has Earnhardt Jr. eyed his next rising star for a while? Well, Rhodes said negotiations date back to this summer, and the deal has been done for a while.

    "Respect this hard tire/speedy dry combo @benrhodes," Earnhardt Jr. tweeted during the Nov. 7 Truck Series race at Phoenix, already offering advice when Rhodes spun early in the race before rallying to a career-best fifth-place finish.

    "Yes, I learned my lesson! #Patience," Rhodes responded afterward.

    There's another link between the Louisville native, who got his start racing go karts regionally and then went on to dominate in bandolero and legends cars. Mark McFarland, a former JR Motorsports driver, crew chiefed Rhodes' K&N car this season.

    "I think he showed some real talent tonight, especially with all his fans here," McFarland said Sept. 19, once Rhodes crashed out of his 1.5-mile track debut in an ARCA race at Kentucky Speedway after leading much of the event. "I think Ben's good enough to go on to the next level and move up from there."

    Jonathan Lintner can be reached at (502) 582-4199. Follow him on Twitter @JonathanLintner.
